citations.narrative:
The facility uses microchips as their form of official identification for cats over 16 weeks of age. There was at least 8 cats
over the age of 16 weeks without a microchip. An acceptable form of official identification (listed below) is necessary for
APHIS officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly trace their movements.
All live cats over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by a
legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or by a microchip placed under the animal’s skin. The licensee must
apply one of these forms of identification to the cats. The licensee must ensure that all cats have an official form of
identification at all times.
To be corrected by: 5-July-2024

Acquisition information for eight adult cats (over 4 months of age) and the disposition date and method for 3 adult cats is
not present on the Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7005). The licensee microchips all kittens before
leaving the facility but has not recorded those microchip numbers on the Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS form
7006). Failure to provide complete and accurate acquisition and disposition information inhibits APHIS's ability to identify
and trace animal movements. Each dealer, other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are
consigned, and each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the
following information concerning each dog or cat purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her
possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer
or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her
control.
To be corrected by: 5-July-2024

Several surfaces in the isolation building holding 4 adult cats had red pitted rust present. A metal baseboard heater, 3
metal self feeders and a metal rack had various stages of rust present, this items were present within the primary
enclosures of the 4 cats. Surfaces with excessive rust prevents cleaning and sanitizing which may create a disease
hazard and may affect the animal's health. The surfaces of housing facilities - including houses, dens, and other furniture-
type fixtures and objects within the facility - must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be
readily cleaned and sanitized, or removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces and any surfaces that come
in contact with dogs or cats must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that
affects the structural strength of the surface.
To be corrected by: 5-July-2024

The water receptacles in the cattery building housing approximately 23 adult cats and 13 kittens are no longer able to be
sanitized. A brown calcium buildup is present in the water receptacles due to hard water at the facility as stated by the
licensee. While the facility has attempted to remove the calcium buildup, it has not removed it. The rough surface of
calcium buildup may cause disease hazards and may affect the health of the animals. Water receptacles must be kept
clean and sanitized in accordance with § 3.11(b).
To be corrected by: 19-July-2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The facility uses microchips as their form of official identification for cats over 16 weeks of age. There was at least 8 cats 
over the age of 16 weeks without a microchip. An acceptable form of official identification (listed below) is necessary for 
APHIS officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly trace their movements. 
All live cats over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by a 
legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or by a microchip placed under the animal’s skin. The licensee must 
apply one of these forms of identification to the cats. The licensee must ensure that all cats have an official form of 
identification at all times. 
To be corrected by: 5-July-2024 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Acquisition information for eight adult cats (over 4 months of age) and the disposition date and method for 3 adult cats is 
not present on the Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7005). The licensee microchips all kittens before 
leaving the facility but has not recorded those microchip numbers on the Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS form 
7006). Failure to provide complete and accurate acquisition and disposition information inhibits APHIS's ability to identify 
and trace animal movements. Each dealer, other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are 
consigned, and each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the 
following information concerning each dog or cat purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her 
possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer 
or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her 
control. 
To be corrected by: 5-July-2024 
3.1(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Several surfaces in the isolation building holding 4 adult cats had red pitted rust present. A metal baseboard heater, 3 
metal self feeders and a metal rack had various stages of rust present, this items were present within the primary 
enclosures of the 4 cats. Surfaces with excessive rust prevents cleaning and sanitizing which may create a disease 
hazard and may affect the animal's health. The surfaces of housing facilities - including houses, dens, and other furniture-

type fixtures and objects within the facility - must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be 
readily cleaned and sanitized, or removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces and any surfaces that come 
in contact with dogs or cats must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that 
affects the structural strength of the surface.  
To be corrected by: 5-July-2024 
3.10(c) 
   
Watering 
The water receptacles in the cattery building housing approximately 23 adult cats and 13 kittens are no longer able to be 
sanitized. A brown calcium buildup is present in the water receptacles due to hard water at the facility as stated by the 
licensee. While the facility has attempted to remove the calcium buildup, it has not removed it. The rough surface of 
calcium buildup may cause disease hazards and may affect the health of the animals. Water receptacles must be kept 
clean and sanitized in accordance with § 3.11(b). 
To be corrected by: 19-July-2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
